Personalized Federated Learning of Probabilistic Models: A PAC-Bayesian Approach

Mahrokh Ghoddousi Boroujeni1, Andreas Krause2, and Giancarlo Ferrari Trecate1
1 Institute of Mechanical Engineering, EPFL, Switzerland
{mahrokh.ghoddousiboroujeni, giancarlo.ferraritrecate}@epfl.ch
2 Department of Computer Science, ETH ZÃ¼rich, Switzerland
krausea@ethz.ch
Abstract

Federated learning aims to infer a shared model from private and decentralized data stored locally by multiple clients. Personalized federated learning (PFL) goes one step further by adapting the global model to each client, enhancing the modelâ€™s fit for different clients. A significant level of personalization is required for highly heterogeneous clients, but can be challenging to achieve especially when they have small datasets. To address this problem, we propose a PFL algorithm named PAC-PFL for learning probabilistic models within a PAC-Bayesian framework that utilizes differential privacy to handle data-dependent priors. Our algorithm collaboratively learns a shared hyper-posterior and regards each clientâ€™s posterior inference as the personalization step. By establishing and minimizing a generalization bound on the average true risk of clients, PAC-PFL effectively combats over-fitting. PAC-PFL achieves accurate and well-calibrated predictions, supported by experiments on a dataset of photovoltaic panel power generation, FEMNIST datasetÂ [Caldas etÂ al., 2019], and Dirichlet-partitioned EMNIST datasetÂ [Cohen etÂ al., 2017].

1 Introduction

Federated Learning (FL) aims at collaboratively learning from multiple private datasets stored by end-devices, called clients [KoneÄnÃ½ etÂ al., 2015]. The main line of FL iteratively trains a global model that performs well for all clients. A trusted server orchestrates the training by sending the model to a subset of the clients at each iteration and collecting model updates from them. The server prepares the model for the next iteration by aggregating these local updates. The server only accesses the communicated model updates and not the clientsâ€™ datasets. Thus, FL offers better data privacy and lowers communication than a data-centric approach, where all clientsâ€™ datasets are sent to the server.

A defining characteristic of FL is that the clientsâ€™ data are potentially heterogeneous [Kairouz etÂ al., 2021, Li etÂ al., 2020a]. This violates the critical i.i.d samples assumption in training a single global model, leading to convergence issues or poor performance [Li etÂ al., 2020b]. Personalized FL (PFL) addresses this challenge by incorporating a further personalization step of adapting the global model to each clientâ€™s data. While PFL has been extensively studied, the following challenges (c111-c444) remain less explored. First, (c111) the majority of PFL approaches yield point estimates of the models, limiting their ability to quantify epistemic uncertainty, which is problematic in safety-critical applications [Guo etÂ al., 2017, Achituve etÂ al., 2021]. Second, (c222) the resulting personalized models remain closely tied and are not fully capable of capturing highly heterogeneous, multimodal scenarios. Third, (c333) many proposed methods suffer from performance degradation when clientsâ€™ datasets are small. Finally, (c444) most approaches do not take into account the collection of new data over time. In this paper, we propose a PFL algorithm, called PAC-PFL, for tackling the challenges outlined above, (c111-c444).

A natural PFL method for probabilistic models is to collaboratively learn a shared prior and regard the posterior inference as the personalization step. However, in this setting, the learned prior depends on each clientâ€™s data, conflicting with the Bayesian framework [Box and Tiao, 1992]. To overcome this, we leverage a PAC-Bayesian technique capable of handling data-dependent priors [Rivasplata etÂ al., 2020] for inferring the posterior and providing uncertainty quantification, hence addressing (c111). However, the clientsâ€™ posterior distributions tend to resemble each other due to their connection with the shared prior, impairing the performance in heterogeneous scenarios (see c222). As an alternative, we collaboratively learn a shared distribution over priors, termed a hyper-posterior, from which the clients sample their priors to perform personalized posterior inference. By removing the linkage of the personalized posteriors to the same shared prior, this approach enhances flexibility in capturing heterogeneous patterns, thus resolving (c222).

To mitigate potential overfitting in low-data scenarios (see c333), we select the hyper-posterior by minimizing a generalization bound on clientsâ€™ true loss. Section 4 will demonstrate that this approach provides a principled regularization of the hyper-posterior, facilitating the learning of complex models without overfitting. Regarding (c444), PAC-PFL accommodates collecting new data over time. Due to practical constraints, only a fraction of clients communicate with the server in each iteration. Before reconnecting with the server, a client may collect new data that can be used for personalization, but not for training the shared hyper-posterior. In an extreme case, there may be clients joining the system later, denoted as new clients, who have never communicated with the server. The distinction between existing and new clients is important, as distinct generalization bounds hold for each group.

We evaluate our framework on Gaussian Process (GP) regression and Bayesian Neural Network (BNN) classification as representative examples of probabilistic models. Our experiments demonstrate that PAC-PFL produces accurate and well-calibrated predictions (c111) even in highly heterogeneous (c222) and data-poor (c333) scenarios. Additionally, we show that PAC-PFL enables positive transfer learning from existing clients to new clients. (c444) Finally, our method can be interpreted through Jaynesâ€™ principle of maximum entropyÂ [Jaynes, 1957] as explained in AppendixÂ 8.1.

2 Related work

Meta-PFL.

PAC-PFL falls under the meta-PFL category [Kulkarni etÂ al., 2020]. Meta-learning, developed independently of FL, involves training a global model on various related learning problems (tasks), which can be efficiently fine-tuned for a new task. The link between meta-learning and PFL was first explored in Jiang etÂ al. [2019], where a method was proposed to simultaneously learn the global model and its personalization. Several methods aim to find a model initialization that performs well after personalization by individual clients using their respective dataÂ [Khodak etÂ al., 2019, Fallah etÂ al., 2020, Chen etÂ al., 2018]. However, the approach of Â Khodak etÂ al. [2019] suffers from scalability issues due to its reliance on sequential updates from clients. On the other hand,Â Fallah etÂ al. [2020] proposes an intuitive algorithm by narrowing the personalization step down to taking one or a few steps of gradient descent with respect to clientsâ€™ own data. However, the personalized models have a high resemblance to the shared model due to the personalization scheme. Additionally, all these methods are frequentist, specific to parametric models, and lack generalization bounds. For a comprehensive overview of PFL, please refer to Kulkarni etÂ al. [2020].

FL for probabilistic models.

Several FL methods aim to learn a global posterior at the server level, which is generally intractable. Accordingly, these studies resort to approximation techniques such as Laplace approximationÂ [Al-Shedivat etÂ al., 2020], Stein Variational Gradient Descent (SVGD)Â [Kassab and Simeone, 2022], and Variational Inference (VI)Â [Bui etÂ al., 2018]. InÂ Corinzia and Buhmann [2019], personalized posteriors are achieved by training global and per-client variational factors jointly, but this method faces scalability issues in systems with many clients since refining personalized models is performed sequentially. While this approach performs well in the tested scenarios, it is expected that the global variational factors cannot capture patterns among highly heterogeneous clients, and the framework becomes equivalent to clients learning solely on their local data, as emphasized by Â Marfoq etÂ al. [2021]. Recently, Zhang etÂ al. [2022] introduced pFedBayes which is a bilevel optimization approach combining a server-level global prior with client-level personalized posteriors. In each round, clients calculate local posteriors by optimizing their data likelihood while adding regularization towards the global prior. The server calculates the prior by minimizing the average client loss. However, this approach, due to its bi-level optimization, imposes a significant computational burden. Additionally, it results in a heuristic posterior, forfeiting the Bayesian interpretation, due to the dependence of the prior on the client data. In contrast, we employ an inference framework, as proposed by Dziugaite and Roy [2018], to handle data-dependent priors. Akin to meta-PFL approaches, regularization towards a global model may limit the degree of personalization achievable.

The closest work to our approach isÂ Achituve etÂ al. [2021], which performs deep kernel learning for GPs by maximizing the average Log Marginal Likelihood (LML) across all clients, learning a shared prior, and regarding the posterior inference as personalization. Our method distinguishes itself from Â Achituve etÂ al. [2021] by learning a distribution over priors instead of a single prior. Moreover, while Â Achituve etÂ al. [2021] only considers zero-mean priors, our approach can learn both the mean and the covariance of the prior distribution. The reason for focusing on covariance learning and ignoring the mean inÂ Achituve etÂ al. [2021] may be that the LML implicitly regularizes the kernel, while the mean can quickly overfit, as suggested inÂ Fortuin etÂ al. [2020]. Our approach overcomes this issue by incorporating a principled regularization term.

PAC-Bayesian meta-learning

The setup described in Section 1 is closely related to meta-learning within the PAC-Bayesian framework Â [Amit and Meir, 2018, Pentina and Lampert, 2014, Rothfuss etÂ al., 2021]. In this scheme, a meta-learner is presented with a sequence of heterogeneous learning tasks and aims to learn a hyper-posterior from previous tasks to facilitate posterior inference for a new unseen task. The meta-learner achieves this by establishing and minimizing a generalization bound on the new task using the previous tasksâ€™ data, establishing a data flow from existing to new tasks. While the mentioned approaches can be used for FL by treating each client as a task, they do not incentivize existing clients to collaborate in the scheme. In contrast, our approach focuses on the existing clients who are the primary concern of an FL system and minimizes a generalization bound on them. Particularly, our approach is an adaptation ofÂ Rothfuss etÂ al. [2021] to PFL, where the key technical difference is dealing with data-dependent priors. Our obtained bounds are structurally similar to those ofÂ Rothfuss etÂ al. [2021], allowing us to leverage similar methods for optimizing the hyper-posterior.

Each client iâˆˆ1,â‹¯,nğ‘–1â‹¯ğ‘›i\in{1,\cdots,n} aims to learn a hypothesis function hi:Rğ±â†’Ry:subscriptâ„ğ‘–absentâ†’subscriptğ‘…ğ±subscriptğ‘…ğ‘¦h_{i}:R_{\mathbf{x}}\xrightarrow{}R_{y} that can be used for predicting the label yâˆ—subscriptğ‘¦y_{*} of an unseen input ğ±âˆ—subscriptğ±\mathbf{x_{*}} drawn from the unknown data distribution ğ’Ÿisubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–\mathcal{D}_{i}. Since the data distribution, ğ’Ÿisubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–\mathcal{D}_{i}, is unknown, standard methods select the best hypothesis according to the set of observed samples, ğ’®iâˆªğ’®~isubscriptğ’®ğ‘–subscript~ğ’®ğ‘–\mathcal{S}_{i}\cup\tilde{\mathcal{S}}_{i}; for instance, by minimizing the empirical risk associated with â„“â„“\ell.

Using a single hypothesis based on limited observations leads to epistemic uncertainty [Draper, 1995] and overconfident target estimation [Kass and Raftery, 1995]. To address this issue, the PAC-Bayesian framework [McAllester, 1999] places probability distributions over the hypothesis space, â„‹â„‹\mathcal{H}, and combines all possible hypotheses sampled from these distributions for making inferences. Two such distributions are enlisted: a prior distribution, Pğ‘ƒP, and a posterior distribution, Qisubscriptğ‘„ğ‘–Q_{i}, which depends on the prior and the observations through a mapping, Qiâ‰”â„šâ€‹(P,ğ’®iâˆªğ’®~i)â‰”subscriptğ‘„ğ‘–â„šğ‘ƒsubscriptğ’®ğ‘–subscript~ğ’®ğ‘–Q_{i}\coloneqq\mathds{Q}(P,\mathcal{S}_{i}\cup\tilde{\mathcal{S}}_{i}). While the prior and posterior terms resemble the Bayesian terminology, the posterior mapping, â„šâ„š\mathds{Q}, is not (necessarily) obtained through Bayesâ€™ theorem. Additionally, recent advances in PAC-Bayesian analysis enable employing priors that depend slightly on the data to make the learning pipeline more data-driven, which is contrary to the Bayesian formalism [Rivasplata etÂ al., 2020].

PAC-Bayes theory [McAllester, 1999] provides a guarantee on the worst loss clients may suffer by upper bounding the unknown true risk inÂ (1) based on the empirical risk inÂ (2). The original PAC bound by McAllester [1999] assumes that the prior, Pğ‘ƒP, is independent of the data. However, in our setup, the prior is obtained from the FL algorithm acting on the data subset ğ’®isubscriptğ’®ğ‘–\mathcal{S}_{i}, hence, is data-dependent. Dziugaite and Roy [2018] propose a recipe for adapting any PAC bound with data-free prior to a data-dependent prior that is stable to slight changes in the data, formalized by the notion of Differential Privacy (DP) defined below.

Definition 3.1 ([Dwork and Roth, 2014]).

Let Ïµiâˆˆâ„+subscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘–subscriptâ„\epsilon_{i}\in\mathbb{R}_{+} and ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A} be a randomized algorithm that takes a dataset as input and generates a stochastic output. where the probability is taken over the randomness used by the algorithm.

Intuitively, (3) states that ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A} is stable w.r.t changing one sample of ğ’®ğ’®\mathcal{S} [Dwork etÂ al., 2015]. The parameter Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon controls the privacy/stability level and is smaller if ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A} is more private/stable.

Randomization in ğ’œğ’®\ğ’®isubscriptğ’œ\ğ’®subscriptğ’®ğ‘–\mathcal{A}_{\mathcal{S}\backslash\mathcal{S}_{i}} arises from sampling the prior from the hyper-posterior.

Remark.

The term Iâ€‹(Ïµi,mi,Î´)ğ¼subscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘–subscriptğ‘šğ‘–ğ›¿I(\epsilon_{i},m_{i},\delta) is the only change from the bound of Alquier etÂ al. [2016] with a data-free prior.

We refer to Theorem 3.1 as the client-level upper bound because it provides a guarantee on the unknown true risk of each client iğ‘–i.

Optimal posterior

The bound in (4) holds for all Qisubscriptğ‘„ğ‘–Q_{i} and thus can be minimized w.r.t Qisubscriptğ‘„ğ‘–Q_{i} to obtain the tightest upper bound on the true risk. Since Ïµisubscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘–\epsilon_{i} only reflects through the term Iğ¼I in (4), the optimal posterior is the same as the minimizer of the bound with a data-free prior derived in Catoni [2007].

Corollary 3.1.1 ([Catoni, 2007]).

Given a prior, Pğ‘ƒP, obtained through an Ïµisubscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘–\epsilon_{i}-DP algorithm and observations, ğ’®iâˆªğ’®~isubscriptğ’®ğ‘–subscript~ğ’®ğ‘–\mathcal{S}_{i}\cup\tilde{\mathcal{S}}_{i}, the optimal posterior minimizing the right-hand side ofÂ (4) is a Gibbs distribution:

Qiâˆ—â‰”â„šâˆ—â€‹(P,ğ’®iâˆªğ’®~i)=Pâ€‹(h)â‹…expâ¡(âˆ’Î²mi+m~iâ€‹âˆ‘ğ³âˆˆğ’®iâˆªğ’®~iâ„“â€‹(h,ğ³))/ZÎ²Câ€‹(P,ğ’®iâˆªğ’®~i),â‰”subscriptsuperscriptğ‘„ğ‘–superscriptâ„šğ‘ƒsubscriptğ’®ğ‘–subscript~ğ’®ğ‘–â‹…ğ‘ƒâ„ğ›½subscriptğ‘šğ‘–subscript~ğ‘šğ‘–subscriptğ³subscriptğ’®ğ‘–subscript~ğ’®ğ‘–â„“â„ğ³subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ¶ğ›½ğ‘ƒsubscriptğ’®ğ‘–subscript~ğ’®ğ‘–\displaystyle Q^{*}_{i}\coloneqq\mathds{Q}^{*}(P,\mathcal{S}_{i}\cup\tilde{\mathcal{S}}_{i})=P(h)\cdot\exp\Bigl{(}\frac{-\beta}{m_{i}+\tilde{m}_{i}}\sum_{\mathbf{z}\in\mathcal{S}_{i}\cup\tilde{\mathcal{S}}_{i}}\ell(h,\mathbf{z})\Bigr{)}/Z^{C}_{\beta}(P,\mathcal{S}_{i}\cup\tilde{\mathcal{S}}_{i}), (5)

where ZÎ²Câ€‹(P,ğ’®iâˆªğ’®~i)â‰”ğ”¼hâˆ¼Pexpâ¡(âˆ’Î²mi+m~iâ€‹âˆ‘ğ³âˆˆğ’®iâˆªğ’®~iâ„“â€‹(h,ğ³))â‰”subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ¶ğ›½ğ‘ƒsubscriptğ’®ğ‘–subscript~ğ’®ğ‘–subscriptğ”¼similar-toâ„ğ‘ƒğ›½subscriptğ‘šğ‘–subscript~ğ‘šğ‘–subscriptğ³subscriptğ’®ğ‘–subscript~ğ’®ğ‘–â„“â„ğ³Z^{C}_{\beta}(P,\mathcal{S}_{i}\cup\tilde{\mathcal{S}}_{i})\coloneqq\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{h\sim P}\exp\Bigl{(}\frac{-\beta}{m_{i}+\tilde{m}_{i}}\sum_{\mathbf{z}\in\mathcal{S}_{i}\cup\tilde{\mathcal{S}}_{i}}\ell(h,\mathbf{z})\Bigr{)} is a normalization constant.

Using the negative log-likelihood loss, â„“â€‹(h,ğ³)â‰”âˆ’lnâ¡Prâ¡[ğ³|h]â‰”â„“â„ğ³Prconditionalğ³â„\ell(h,\mathbf{z})\coloneqq-\ln\Pr[\mathbf{z}|h] and Î²=mi+m~iğ›½subscriptğ‘šğ‘–subscript~ğ‘šğ‘–\beta=m_{i}+\tilde{m}_{i}, reduces ZÎ²Csubscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ¶ğ›½Z^{C}_{\beta} to the LML and the Gibbs posterior coincides with the Bayes posterior [Guedj, 2019].

Plugging in the closed-form formula of the optimal posteriorÂ (5) into the client-level bound obtains:

â„’Câ€‹(â„šâˆ—â€‹(P,ğ’®iâˆªğ’®~i),ğ’Ÿi)â‰¤superscriptâ„’ğ¶superscriptâ„šğ‘ƒsubscriptğ’®ğ‘–subscript~ğ’®ğ‘–subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–absent\displaystyle\mathcal{L}^{C}\big{(}\mathds{Q}^{*}(P,\mathcal{S}_{i}\cup\tilde{\mathcal{S}}_{i}),\mathcal{D}_{i}\big{)}\leq 1Î²â€‹(âˆ’lnâ¡ZÎ²â€‹(P,ğ’®iâˆªğ’®~i)+Î²2â€‹(bâˆ’a)28â€‹(mi+m~i)+Iâ€‹(Ïµi,mi,Î´)+lnâ¡(1Î´)),1ğ›½subscriptğ‘ğ›½ğ‘ƒsubscriptğ’®ğ‘–subscript~ğ’®ğ‘–superscriptğ›½2superscriptğ‘ğ‘28subscriptğ‘šğ‘–subscript~ğ‘šğ‘–ğ¼subscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘–subscriptğ‘šğ‘–ğ›¿1ğ›¿\displaystyle\frac{1}{\beta}\Big{(}-\ln{Z_{\beta}(P,\mathcal{S}_{i}\cup\tilde{\mathcal{S}}_{i})}+\frac{\beta^{2}(b-a)^{2}}{8(m_{i}+\tilde{m}_{i})}+I(\epsilon_{i},m_{i},\delta)+\ln{(\frac{1}{\delta})}\Big{)}, (6)

holding with probability at least 1âˆ’Î´1ğ›¿1-\delta over ğ’®iâˆ¼ğ’Ÿimi,S~iâˆ¼ğ’Ÿim~iformulae-sequencesimilar-tosubscriptğ’®ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–subscriptğ‘šğ‘–similar-tosubscript~ğ‘†ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–subscript~ğ‘šğ‘–\mathcal{S}_{i}\sim\mathcal{D}_{i}^{m_{i}},\tilde{S}_{i}\sim\mathcal{D}_{i}^{\tilde{m}_{i}}. The simplified boundÂ (6) removes the explicit dependence on Qisubscriptğ‘„ğ‘–Q_{i} and is tighter than the generic bound perÂ (4).

In the rest of this paper, we assume that clients utilize Qiâˆ—subscriptsuperscriptğ‘„ğ‘–Q^{*}_{i} whenever the privacy requirement of Theorem 3.1 is satisfied. This is a mild assumption bearing into mind that the family of Gibbs posteriors (for different choices of â„“â„“\ell and Î²ğ›½\beta) encompasses the Bayes posterior.

4 Theoretical framework for PAC-Bayesian federated learning

Overview of the approach.

Having defined basic components, we reemphasize the main research problem. In this paper, we employ FL to select the prior distribution in a data-driven manner. With a similar justification of considering distributions over hypotheses, we formulate two distributions over priors: a hyper-prior, ğ’«ğ’«\mathcal{P}, and a hyper-posterior, ğ’¬ğ’¬\mathcal{Q}. The hyper-prior must be independent of observations, while the hyper-posterior depends on the observed samples by clients.

We assume the existence of a trusted server communicating with a set of existing clients, 1,â‹¯,n1â‹¯ğ‘›1,\cdots,n, each holding a set of observed samples, ğ’®1,â‹¯,ğ’®nsubscriptğ’®1â‹¯subscriptğ’®ğ‘›\mathcal{S}_{1},\cdots,\mathcal{S}_{n}. The server aims to extract common knowledge in the form of a hyper-posterior distribution without directly accessing clientsâ€™ datasets (as enforced by FL). The server communicates the learned hyper-posterior to clients, including those who participated in federated training and some new ones. The clients proceed by repeatedly drawing a prior from the received hyper-posterior and using it to calculate the optimal posterior perÂ (5), involving any potential additional samples, ğ’®~isubscript~ğ’®ğ‘–\tilde{\mathcal{S}}_{i} in the inference procedure. The goal is to find the optimal hyper-posterior, ğ’¬âˆ—superscriptğ’¬\mathcal{Q}^{*}, such that the posterior obtained through the described pipeline has a low true riskÂ (1) for all clients. An overview of the setup is depicted in Fig.Â 1.

In the sequel, we consider hyper-posteriors, ğ’¬ğ’¬\mathcal{Q}, that satisfy the condition of having a finite Ïµâˆˆâ„+italic-Ïµsubscriptâ„\epsilon\in\mathbb{R}_{+} such that sampling Pğ‘ƒP from ğ’¬ğ’¬\mathcal{Q} preserves Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon-DP for all clients. This assumption enables us to use CorollaryÂ 3.1.1 and is rather weak as Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon can be arbitrarily, albeit not infinitely, large. Analogous to the procedure in SectionÂ 3, we establish PAC bounds for the pair ğ’«ğ’«\mathcal{P} and ğ’¬ğ’¬\mathcal{Q}. We derive a closed-form formula for the optimal hyper-posterior, ğ’¬âˆ—superscriptğ’¬\mathcal{Q}^{*}, which minimizes the PAC bound, and verify that ğ’¬âˆ—superscriptğ’¬\mathcal{Q}^{*} satisfies the privacy assumption. Finally, we establish a PAC bound for new clients who sample their priors from ğ’¬âˆ—superscriptğ’¬\mathcal{Q}^{*} without participating in the federated learning process. An interpretation through the principle of maximum entropyÂ [Jaynes, 1957] and all proofs are provided in AppendicesÂ 8.1 and 8.2, respectively.

Server-level PAC-Bayesian bound.

Following the introduced inference setup, the quality of ğ’¬ğ’¬\mathcal{Q} can be measured by server-level true risk, defined as:

â„’Sâ€‹(ğ’¬,ğ’Ÿ,ğ’®,ğ¦~)superscriptâ„’ğ‘†ğ’¬ğ’Ÿğ’®~ğ¦\displaystyle\mathcal{L}^{S}(\mathcal{Q},\mathcal{D},\mathcal{S},\mathbf{\tilde{m}}) â‰”1nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1nğ”¼Pâˆ¼ğ’¬ğ”¼ğ’®~iâˆ¼ğ’Ÿim~iâ¡â„’Câ€‹(â„šâˆ—â€‹(P,ğ’®iâˆªğ’®~i),ğ’Ÿi).â‰”absent1ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›subscriptğ”¼similar-toğ‘ƒğ’¬subscriptğ”¼similar-tosubscript~ğ’®ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–subscript~ğ‘šğ‘–superscriptâ„’ğ¶superscriptâ„šğ‘ƒsubscriptğ’®ğ‘–subscript~ğ’®ğ‘–subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–\displaystyle\coloneqq\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{P\sim\mathcal{Q}}\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\tilde{\mathcal{S}}_{i}\sim\mathcal{D}_{i}^{\tilde{m}_{i}}}\mathcal{L}^{C}(\mathds{Q}^{*}(P,\mathcal{S}_{i}\cup\tilde{\mathcal{S}}_{i}),\mathcal{D}_{i}). (7)

Equation (7) averages the true loss across all clients, accounting for every possible set of new samples, ğ’®~~ğ’®\tilde{\mathcal{S}}, with sizes specified by ğ¦~~ğ¦\mathbf{\tilde{m}}. The data generating distributions ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D} are unknown in the true loss definition per (7), calling for an empirical estimation merely based on the available information:

â„’^Sâ€‹(ğ’¬,ğ’®)superscript^â„’ğ‘†ğ’¬ğ’®\displaystyle\hat{\mathcal{L}}^{S}(\mathcal{Q},\mathcal{S}) â‰”1nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1nğ”¼Pâˆ¼ğ’¬â„’^Câ€‹(â„šâˆ—â€‹(P,ğ’®i),ğ’®i),â‰”absent1ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›subscriptğ”¼similar-toğ‘ƒğ’¬superscript^â„’ğ¶superscriptâ„šğ‘ƒsubscriptğ’®ğ‘–subscriptğ’®ğ‘–\displaystyle\coloneqq\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{P\sim\mathcal{Q}}\hat{\mathcal{L}}^{C}(\mathds{Q}^{*}(P,\mathcal{S}_{i}),\mathcal{S}_{i}), (8)

where observed samples replace potential future data. We refer to (8) as the server-level empirical loss because it can be computed by the server by collecting summands from clients.

Below, we present our first main contribution, which is a PAC bound on server-level risks.

Theorem 4.1.

The constant Ï…ğœ\upsilon can be chosen very small and avoids numerical issues when n2=0subscriptğ‘›20n_{2}=0. The bound inÂ (9) depends on the number of clients and the current dataset sizes, nğ‘›n and ğ¦ğ¦\mathbf{m}. Additionally, it relies on a prediction of the number of clients who will have new samples and the corresponding number of new samples, n2subscriptğ‘›2n_{2} and ğ¦~~ğ¦\mathbf{\tilde{m}}. While the server knows nğ‘›n and ğ¦ğ¦\mathbf{m}, the estimates for n2subscriptğ‘›2n_{2} and ğ¦~~ğ¦\mathbf{\tilde{m}} might be coarse. The following lemma states that a pessimistic forecast results in a looser upper bound.

Lemma 4.2.

If the number of new samples of client iğ‘–i, m~iâ‰¥0subscript~ğ‘šğ‘–0\tilde{m}_{i}\geq 0, is unknown, TheoremÂ 4.1 holds when replacing Î”isubscriptÎ”ğ‘–\Delta_{i} with (bâˆ’a)/nğ‘ğ‘ğ‘›(b-a)/n and counting client iğ‘–i in n2subscriptğ‘›2n_{2}, i.e., as if m~i>0subscript~ğ‘šğ‘–0\tilde{m}_{i}>0.

The asymptotic behavior and non-vacuousness of the client-level and server-level bounds are discussed in Appendix 8.3.1.

Optimal hyper-posterior.

Our algorithm picks the optimal hyper-posterior, ğ’¬âˆ—superscriptğ’¬\mathcal{Q}^{*}, leading to the lowest upper bound on the server-level true risk per (4). Inspecting the structural similarity between the server and client-level bounds in (4) and (9), we arrive at a closed-form formula for ğ’¬âˆ—superscriptğ’¬\mathcal{Q}^{*}.

Corollary 4.2.1.

When clients use the optimal posterior, Qiâˆ—subscriptsuperscriptğ‘„ğ‘–Q^{*}_{i}, the optimal hyper-posterior is a Gibbs distribution with parameter Ï„=Î»/(Î»+Î²â€‹nâ€‹(n2+Ï…))ğœğœ†ğœ†ğ›½ğ‘›subscriptğ‘›2ğœ\tau=\lambda/\big{(}\lambda+\beta n(n_{2}+\upsilon)\big{)}:

where ZÏ„Sâ€‹(ğ’«,ğ’®)â‰”ğ”¼Pâˆ¼ğ’«expâ¡(Ï„â€‹âˆ‘i=1nlnâ¡(ZÎ²Câ€‹(P,ğ’®i)))â‰”subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘†ğœğ’«ğ’®subscriptğ”¼similar-toğ‘ƒğ’«ğœsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ¶ğ›½ğ‘ƒsubscriptğ’®ğ‘–Z^{S}_{\tau}(\mathcal{P},\mathcal{S})\coloneqq\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{P\sim\mathcal{P}}\exp\big{(}\tau\sum_{i=1}^{n}\ln\big{(}Z^{C}_{\beta}(P,\mathcal{S}_{i})\big{)}\big{)} is a normalization constant.

The parameter Ï„ğœ\tau depends on the number of clients from different types, nğ‘›n and n2subscriptğ‘›2n_{2}, but not on the number of samples, ğ¦ğ¦\mathbf{m} and ğ¦~~ğ¦\mathbf{\tilde{m}}. If n2subscriptğ‘›2n_{2} is unknown, it can be replaced by counting iğ‘–i in n2subscriptğ‘›2n_{2}, consistently with LemmaÂ 4.2. In this case, a looser upper bound would be minimized.

The privacy of sampling a prior from ğ’¬âˆ—superscriptğ’¬\mathcal{Q}^{*} is crucial to obtain Ïµisubscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘–\epsilon_{i} for plugging it into the client-level bound (6) and for employing Theorem 4.1. We rely on a result by Mir [2012] that proves the DP of sampling from the Gibbs distribution.

Lemma 4.3.

A prior sampled from ğ’¬âˆ—superscriptğ’¬\mathcal{Q}^{*} preserves Ïµisubscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘–\epsilon_{i}-DP for client iğ‘–i, where Ïµi=2â€‹Î²â€‹Ï„â€‹(bâˆ’a)/misubscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘–2ğ›½ğœğ‘ğ‘subscriptğ‘šğ‘–\epsilon_{i}=2\beta\tau(b-a)/m_{i} .

As a result, ğ’¬âˆ—superscriptğ’¬\mathcal{Q}^{*} satisfies the privacy assumption of Theorem 4.1 with Ïµ=maxiâˆˆ{1,â‹¯,n}â¡Ïµiitalic-Ïµsubscriptğ‘–1â‹¯ğ‘›subscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘–\epsilon=\max_{i\in\{1,\cdots,n\}}\epsilon_{i}. Complementary discussions regarding the role of DP in our framework are available in Appendix 8.4.

PAC-Bayesian bound for new clients.

So far, we considered a fixed set of existing clients who participate in training the optimal hyper-posterior. In a realistic FL setup, there might be new clients (see c444) who join the system later and hence, do not engage in federated training. A new client holds a presumably small set of samples which leads to overfitting. Assuming the existing and new clients are similar, it is constructive for the new clients to readily employ ğ’¬âˆ—superscriptğ’¬\mathcal{Q}^{*} without having contributed to training it. In this section, we establish a PAC bound for such new clients.

In Section 3, we introduced the distribution ğ’¯ğ’¯\mathcal{T} to represent the similarity among the existing clients. Consistently, we expect that a new client Î¹ğœ„\iota is sampled from the same distribution, (ğ’ŸÎ¹,m~Î¹)âˆ¼ğ’¯similar-tosubscriptğ’Ÿğœ„subscript~ğ‘šğœ„ğ’¯(\mathcal{D}_{\iota},\tilde{m}_{\iota})\sim\mathcal{T}. In line with the previous notation, m~Î¹subscript~ğ‘šğœ„\tilde{m}_{\iota} is the cardinality of the set ğ’®~Î¹âˆ¼ğ’ŸÎ¹m~Î¹similar-tosubscript~ğ’®ğœ„superscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğœ„subscript~ğ‘šğœ„\tilde{\mathcal{S}}_{\iota}\sim\mathcal{D}_{\iota}^{\tilde{m}_{\iota}} employed by client Î¹ğœ„\iota for personalization but held out from FL. We present below our second PAC-Bayesian bound.

Lemma 4.4.

For a new client Î¹ğœ„\iota sampled from ğ’¯ğ’¯\mathcal{T} adopting â„šâˆ—superscriptâ„š\mathds{Q}^{*} and ğ’¬âˆ—superscriptğ’¬\mathcal{Q}^{*} as per Corollaries 3.1.1, 4.2.1,

ğ”¼(ğ’ŸÎ¹,m~Î¹)âˆ¼ğ’¯ğ”¼ğ’®~Î¹âˆ¼ğ’ŸÎ¹m~Î¹ğ”¼Pâˆ¼ğ’¬âˆ—â¡â„’Câ€‹(â„šâˆ—â€‹(P,ğ’®~Î¹),ğ’ŸÎ¹)â‰¤subscriptğ”¼similar-tosubscriptğ’Ÿğœ„subscript~ğ‘šğœ„ğ’¯subscriptğ”¼similar-tosubscript~ğ’®ğœ„superscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğœ„subscript~ğ‘šğœ„subscriptğ”¼similar-toğ‘ƒsuperscriptğ’¬superscriptâ„’ğ¶superscriptâ„šğ‘ƒsubscript~ğ’®ğœ„subscriptğ’Ÿğœ„absent\displaystyle\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{(\mathcal{D}_{\iota},\tilde{m}_{\iota})\sim\mathcal{T}}\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\tilde{\mathcal{S}}_{\iota}\sim\mathcal{D}_{\iota}^{\tilde{m}_{\iota}}}\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{P\sim\mathcal{Q}^{*}}\mathcal{L}^{C}\big{(}\mathds{Q}^{*}(P,\tilde{\mathcal{S}}_{\iota}),\mathcal{D}_{\iota}\big{)}\leq âˆ’(1nâ€‹Î²+n2+Ï…Î»)â€‹lnâ¡ZÏ„Sâ€‹(ğ’«,ğ’®)1ğ‘›ğ›½subscriptğ‘›2ğœğœ†subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘†ğœğ’«ğ’®\displaystyle-(\frac{1}{n\beta}+\frac{n_{2}+\upsilon}{\lambda})\ln Z^{S}_{\tau}(\mathcal{P},\mathcal{S})

holds with probability at least 1âˆ’Î´1ğ›¿1-\delta over (ğ’ŸÎ¹,m~Î¹)âˆ¼ğ’¯similar-tosubscriptğ’Ÿğœ„subscript~ğ‘šğœ„ğ’¯(\mathcal{D}_{\iota},\tilde{m}_{\iota})\sim\mathcal{T} and ğ’®~Î¹âˆ¼ğ’ŸÎ¹m~Î¹similar-tosubscript~ğ’®ğœ„superscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğœ„subscript~ğ‘šğœ„\tilde{\mathcal{S}}_{\iota}\sim\mathcal{D}_{\iota}^{\tilde{m}_{\iota}}.

Since ğ’¬âˆ—superscriptğ’¬\mathcal{Q}^{*} is tailored to minimize the server-level bound for existing clients, the bound in LemmaÂ 4.4 is looser than that of Theorem 4.1 with ğ’¬=ğ’¬âˆ—ğ’¬superscriptğ’¬\mathcal{Q}=\mathcal{Q}^{*} (see Appendix 8.2.5 for the proof). This motivates the clients to actively engage in training ğ’¬âˆ—superscriptğ’¬\mathcal{Q}^{*} rather than readily employing the learned hyper-posterior.

5 Practical federated implementation

In SectionÂ 3, we motivated learning a distribution over priors when dealing with heterogeneous clients, where selecting a single best prior may not be accurate or feasible. Consequently, we derived the optimal hyper-posterior in Corollary 4.2.1. In this section, we address the computational limitations at both the client and server levels and propose a practical PFL algorithm.

Models at the client level.

The formula for ğ’¬âˆ—superscriptğ’¬\mathcal{Q}^{*} in Corollary 4.2.1 relies on ZÎ²Câ€‹(P,ğ’®i)superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ›½ğ¶ğ‘ƒsubscriptğ’®ğ‘–Z_{\beta}^{C}(P,\mathcal{S}_{i}) for iâˆˆ{0,â‹¯,n}ğ‘–0â‹¯ğ‘›i\in\{0,\cdots,n\}. As per CorollaryÂ 3.1.1, calculating ZÎ²Câ€‹(P,ğ’®i)superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ›½ğ¶ğ‘ƒsubscriptğ’®ğ‘–Z_{\beta}^{C}(P,\mathcal{S}_{i}) entails computing the expectation over all hypotheses sampled from the prior, which is in general intractable. We consider the negative log-likelihood loss and set Î²=mi+m~iğ›½subscriptğ‘šğ‘–subscript~ğ‘šğ‘–\beta=m_{i}+\tilde{m}_{i}, which results in ZÎ²subscriptğ‘ğ›½Z_{\beta} aligning with the LML, as discussed in Section 3. We calculate the LML in two scenarios: when clients use Gaussian Processes (GPs) or Bayesian Neural Networks (BNNs). MLL is readily available in closed-form for GPs but is intractable for BNNs. To address this, we adopt the approximation method described in Rothfuss etÂ al. [2021].

Inspired by Fortuin etÂ al. [2020], Rothfuss etÂ al. [2021], we parameterize the GP mean and kernel by two deep neural networks (NN) and consider a Gaussian likelihood. The resulting model enhances the expressive power and scalability to high-dimensional data of GPs [Wilson etÂ al., 2016]. Additional details about the models and likelihood formulas can be found in Appendices 8.3.2 and 8.3.3.

SVGD at the server level.

Given ZÎ²Câ€‹(P,ğ’®i)superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ›½ğ¶ğ‘ƒsubscriptğ’®ğ‘–Z_{\beta}^{C}(P,\mathcal{S}_{i}), ğ’¬âˆ—superscriptğ’¬\mathcal{Q}^{*} is computable up to the constant ZÏ„Sâ€‹(ğ’«,ğ’®)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘†ğœğ’«ğ’®Z^{S}_{\tau}(\mathcal{P},\mathcal{S}), which leaves sampling from ğ’¬âˆ—superscriptğ’¬\mathcal{Q}^{*} intractable. Following Rothfuss etÂ al. [2021], we use Stein Variational Gradient Descent (SVGD) [Liu and Wang, 2016] that approximates ğ’¬âˆ—superscriptğ’¬\mathcal{Q}^{*} as a set of priors, PÏ•1,â‹¯,PÏ•ksubscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptbold-italic-Ï•1â‹¯subscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptbold-italic-Ï•ğ‘˜P_{\bm{\phi}_{1}},\cdots,P_{\bm{\phi}_{k}}. Each prior PÏ•Îºsubscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptbold-italic-Ï•ğœ…P_{\bm{\phi}_{\kappa}} is parameterized by Ï•Îºsubscriptbold-italic-Ï•ğœ…\bm{\phi}_{\kappa}. SVGD is initialized with a set of priors and then iteratively transports them to match ğ’¬âˆ—superscriptğ’¬\mathcal{Q}^{*}. This is achieved through a form of functional gradient descent on the SVGD loss (see AppendixÂ 8.3.4), making it suitable for being integrated into an FL scheme. As SVGD is deterministicÂ [Liu, 2017], the inherent privacy of ğ’¬âˆ—superscriptğ’¬\mathcal{Q}^{*} established in Lemma 4.3 is compromised. To reintroduce privacy, a conventional approach involves injecting noise into the SVGD gradientsÂ [Geyer etÂ al., 2017]. We propose a privacy-preserving variant of PAC-PFL in AppendixÂ 8.4.

Federated algorithm.

PAC-PFL leverages the FedAvg [McMahan etÂ al., 2016] technique to minimize the SVGD loss. Initially, we sample PÏ•1,â‹¯,PÏ•ksubscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptbold-italic-Ï•1â‹¯subscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptbold-italic-Ï•ğ‘˜P_{\bm{\phi}_{1}},\cdots,P_{\bm{\phi}_{k}} from ğ’«ğ’«\mathcal{P}, which we define as a multi-variate Gaussian distribution with a diagonal covariance matrix. At each iteration, the server randomly selects a subset of existing clients to send Ï•1,â‹¯,Ï•ksubscriptbold-italic-Ï•1â‹¯subscriptbold-italic-Ï•ğ‘˜\bm{\phi}_{1},\cdots,\bm{\phi}_{k}. The selected clients compute the SVGD gradients and send them back to the server. The server aggregates all gradients before using them to update the priors. A pseudocode is presented in Algorithm 1 with sub-routines Client_Update and SVGD_Update defined in AppendixÂ 8.3.5. For a comprehensive list of parameters used in our theoretical results and algorithm, along with selection guidelines, please refer to Appendix 8.3.6.

6 Experiments

We evaluate PAC-PFL on four datasets: photovoltaic (PV) panels and polynomial datasets for regression, alongside FEMNISTÂ [Caldas etÂ al., 2019] and EMNISTÂ [Cohen etÂ al., 2017] datasets for classification. Our algorithm consistently outperforms federated and data-centric baselines, improving the prediction accuracy and the calibration of uncertainty estimates simultaneously. These enhancements are evident in reducing the variance and mean of these metrics across existing and new clients.

Datasets.

The PV dataset contains the PV generation time-series of multiple houses in a city. Each house is a client, and the clients are heterogeneous due to variations in location, shadows, and orientation relative to the sun. We consider 242424 existing and 242424 new clients. This section uses a highly heterogeneous scenario, called PV-EW, with a bimodal distribution over the clients: half oriented eastward and half westward. We use the PV-EW dataset once with 150150150 and once with 610610610 training samples per client. This dataset induces challenges (c111-c444).

The FEMNIST dataset consists of handwritten characters from various writers, treated as clients, and we employ it for 101010-way digit classification. Heterogeneity arises from distinct handwriting (c222). We select 404040 clients and examine two scenarios: one with 202020 and another with an average of 500500500 samples per client. In the low-data case (c333), we demonstrate PAC-PFLâ€™s superior performance over all baselines. In the full-data case, we highlight the scalability of our algorithm with large datasets. The Polynomial and EMNIST datasets and other setups for using the PV dataset are detailed in AppendixÂ 8.5. A summary of the employed datasets is provided in TableÂ 1.

Baselines.

We compare PAC-PFL against two probabilistic PFL methods, pFedGP [Achituve etÂ al., 2021] and pFedBayes [Zhang etÂ al., 2022], and two frequentist PFL methods, MAML [Fallah etÂ al., 2020] and MTL [Evgeniou and Pontil, 2004]. Additionally, we consider two non-federated approaches: Vanilla, where each client trains a model individually, and Pooled, where a single model is trained in a data-centric manner on a pooled dataset comprising all clientsâ€™ data. The Pooled approach is expected to perform poorly for heterogeneous clients due to the lack of personalization. Hyper-parameters for each method are tuned using cross-validation. Further baseline details can be found in Appendix 8.6.

Metrics.

We assess prediction accuracy and calibration for each client. For regression, we use root standardized mean squared error (RSMSE) that normalizes RMSE by the standard deviation of targets. For classification, we measure the percentage of correctly classified samples. Additionally, we compute the calibration error (CE), which quantifies the deviation of predicted confidence intervals from actual proportions of test data within those intervalsÂ [Kuleshov etÂ al., 2018], using the formula inÂ Rothfuss etÂ al. [2021] (see 8.6.1). CE applies exclusively to probabilistic models and is irrelevant to frequentist baselines, such as MAML and MTL. In evaluating FL methods, the sample mean of a metric is often a biased estimate due to correlations across clients. We utilize box plots to analyze the distribution of metric values across clients, offering a more comprehensive understanding.

Results

The results for PV-EW (150) are presented in Fig. 2, highlighting several key findings. MAML does not perform well, likely because a single gradient descent step lacks the necessary personalization (c222), while MTL and pFedGP showcase their capability to capture heterogeneity. The limited sample size (c333) adversely impacts the performance of the local Vanilla GP. Notably, our method outperforms all baselines due to its strong personalization capability, addressing (c222), and inherent regularization, resolving (c333).

Test accuracy percentage on the FEMNIST dataset with 202020 samples per client and the EMNIST dataset for existing clients is provided in TableÂ 2. Remarkably, PAC-PFL outperforms other baselines on both datasets. Complementary experimental results are reported in Appendix 8.6.

7 Conclusion

This paper presents PAC-PFL, a novel PFL algorithm that enables the learning of probabilistic models. The proposed approach learns a shared hyper-posterior in a federated manner, which clients use to sample their priors for personalized posterior inference. To prevent overfitting, PAC-PFL minimizes an upper bound on the true risk of the clients participating in federated training. Moreover, the learned hyper-posterior can be applied to new clients who did not participate in the training, resulting in positive transfer. Conducting experiments on a heterogeneous dataset of PV panels and on the FEMNIST dataset, we empirically demonstrate that PAC-PFL produces accurate and well-calibrated predictions.

There are two main directions for future research: improving client-level computational complexity (detailed in AppendixÂ 8.3.7) and addressing the privacy-utility trade-off more effectively. Our framework leverages DP to derive valid generalization bounds despite having data-dependent priors and to avoid data leakage, as typical in FL. While our theoretical results in Section 4 show that our ideal pipeline provides DP, we forfeit this property due to the SVGD approximation technique. We empirically validated that PAC-PFL avoids overfitting, though the bounds might not hold. DP can be reintroduced to prevent data leakage using the common method of injecting noise during training [Geyer etÂ al., 2017], as demonstrated in Appendix 8.4, but this may compromise accuracy [Bagdasaryan etÂ al., 2019]. Exploring alternative privacy techniques is an avenue for future research.

Reproducibility statement

For all theorems and theoretical results, we present detailed assumptions and proofs in Appendix 8.2. Moreover, we provide a comprehensive table containing all parameters utilized throughout the paper in Appendix 8.3.6. This table highlights the interconnections between these parameters and marks the free parameters that can be tuned for optimal utilization of our algorithm.

Regarding the datasets, we employ the FEMNIST dataset, which is curated and maintained by the LEAF project [Caldas etÂ al., 2019]. We utilize the original train-test split provided with the data, without any additional preprocessing. The PV dataset can be accessed via the following link: https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/153MeAlntN4VORHdgYQ3wG3OylW0SlBf9?usp=sharing.

The source code for our PAC-PFL implementation using GP is accessible within the same Google Drive repository. Upon acceptance, we intend to make the source code for BNN publicly available. To facilitate the use of our software, we have incorporated a demonstration Jupyter Notebook in the source code repository. Furthermore, we have included pre-trained models for PAC-PFL and other baseline models for the PV dataset. Finally, we provide a notebook that generates the figures featured in the paper.

8 Appendix

8.1 Interpretation through the principle of maximum entropy

In this section, we provide additional justification for the optimal hyper-posterior derived in CorollaryÂ 4.2.1 based on the principle of maximum entropy [Jaynes, 1957]. The principle of maximum entropy suggests that when only the class of a distribution is known, the distribution with the highest entropy should be chosen as the least-informative default. The distribution class can be specified by certain moment constraints.This principle is motivated by two key reasons: first, maximizing entropy minimizes the amount of prior information embedded in the distribution, allowing for a more agnostic representation; second, it aligns with the observation that many physical systems tend to evolve towards configurations of maximal entropy over time. While the principle of maximum entropy is commonly employed to derive prior probability distributions in Bayesian inference [Merwe and Skilling, 2010], we utilize it in the context of obtaining the optimal hyper-posterior distribution.

Consider the following constrained maximum entropy problem:

maxğ’¬â¡Hğ’«â€‹(ğ’¬)subscriptğ’¬subscriptğ»ğ’«ğ’¬\displaystyle\max_{\mathcal{Q}}\;H_{\mathcal{P}}(\mathcal{Q}) (10a)
s.t.âˆ’ğ”¼Pâˆ¼ğ’¬lnâ¡ZÎ²â€‹(P,ğ’®i)+Iâ€‹(Ïµi,mi,Î´)â‰¤âˆ’ğ”¼Pâˆ¼ğ’«lnâ¡ZÎ²â€‹(P,ğ’®i)âˆ€iâˆˆ{1,â‹¯,n}.formulae-sequences.t.subscriptğ”¼similar-toğ‘ƒğ’¬subscriptğ‘ğ›½ğ‘ƒsubscriptğ’®ğ‘–ğ¼subscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘–subscriptğ‘šğ‘–ğ›¿subscriptğ”¼similar-toğ‘ƒğ’«subscriptğ‘ğ›½ğ‘ƒsubscriptğ’®ğ‘–for-allğ‘–1â‹¯ğ‘›\displaystyle\textit{s.t.}\;-\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{P\sim\mathcal{Q}}\ln Z_{\beta}(P,\mathcal{S}_{i})+I(\epsilon_{i},m_{i},\delta)\leq-\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{P\sim\mathcal{P}}\ln Z_{\beta}(P,\mathcal{S}_{i})\quad\forall i\in\{1,\cdots,n\}. (10b)

In Equation (10a), Hğ’«â€‹(ğ’¬)=âˆ’Kâ€‹Lâ€‹(ğ’¬âˆ¥ğ’«)subscriptğ»ğ’«ğ’¬ğ¾ğ¿conditionalğ’¬ğ’«H_{\mathcal{P}}(\mathcal{Q})=-KL(\mathcal{Q}\|\mathcal{P}) represents Jaynesâ€™ entropy with the hyper-prior ğ’«ğ’«\mathcal{P} serving as the invariant measure [Jaynes, 1957]. The objective is to maximize this entropy subject to nğ‘›n constraints on the expectations of lnâ¡ZÎ²â€‹(P,ğ’®i)subscriptğ‘ğ›½ğ‘ƒsubscriptğ’®ğ‘–\ln Z_{\beta}(P,\mathcal{S}_{i}) under the distribution ğ’¬ğ’¬\mathcal{Q}, as given in (10b). The constants Ïµisubscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘–\epsilon_{i} and Iâ€‹(Ïµi,mi,Î´)ğ¼subscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘–subscriptğ‘šğ‘–ğ›¿I(\epsilon_{i},m_{i},\delta) are determined by LemmaÂ 4.3 and Theorem 3.1, respectively. Below, we establish a connection between the maximum entropy problem and our approach in Section 4.

Proposition 1.

argâ¡maxğ’¬â¡Hğ’«â€‹(ğ’¬)+Ï„â€‹âˆ‘i=1n(ğ”¼Pâˆ¼ğ’¬lnâ¡ZÎ²â€‹(P,ğ’®i)âˆ’Iâ€‹(Ïµi,mi,Î´)âˆ’ğ”¼Pâˆ¼ğ’«lnâ¡ZÎ²â€‹(P,ğ’®i)),subscriptğ’¬subscriptğ»ğ’«ğ’¬ğœsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›subscriptğ”¼similar-toğ‘ƒğ’¬subscriptğ‘ğ›½ğ‘ƒsubscriptğ’®ğ‘–ğ¼subscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘–subscriptğ‘šğ‘–ğ›¿subscriptğ”¼similar-toğ‘ƒğ’«subscriptğ‘ğ›½ğ‘ƒsubscriptğ’®ğ‘–\displaystyle\arg\max_{\mathcal{Q}}\;H_{\mathcal{P}}(\mathcal{Q})+\tau\sum_{i=1}^{n}\Bigl{(}\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{P\sim\mathcal{Q}}\ln Z_{\beta}(P,\mathcal{S}_{i})-I(\epsilon_{i},m_{i},\delta)-\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{P\sim\mathcal{P}}\ln Z_{\beta}(P,\mathcal{S}_{i})\Bigr{)}, (11)

where the Lagrange multiplier Ï„ğœ\tau is used for all constraints. The constant Ï„ğœ\tau is as per Corollary 4.2.1.

Proof.

The maximum entropy interpretation of ğ’¬âˆ—superscriptğ’¬\mathcal{Q}^{*} allows us to analyze the effect of sampling Pğ‘ƒP from ğ’¬âˆ—superscriptğ’¬\mathcal{Q}^{*} on client-level bounds. If client iğ‘–i chooses not to participate in FL and decides not to use ğ’¬âˆ—superscriptğ’¬\mathcal{Q}^{*}, the best alternative approach is to sample Pğ‘ƒP from ğ’«ğ’«\mathcal{P}. The following corollary provides a comparison between sampling Pğ‘ƒP from ğ’¬âˆ—superscriptğ’¬\mathcal{Q}^{*} and sampling Pğ‘ƒP from ğ’«ğ’«\mathcal{P}.

Corollary 8.0.1.

The iğ‘–i-th constraint in (10b) imposes that the expected upper bound for client iğ‘–i is tighter when sampling the prior Pğ‘ƒP from the optimal hyper-posterior, ğ’¬âˆ—superscriptğ’¬\mathcal{Q}^{*}, compared to sampling from the hyper-prior, ğ’«ğ’«\mathcal{P}.

Proof.

Since a prior which is sampled from the hyper-prior is no longer data-dependent, we utilize the result from Alquier etÂ al. [2016] to derive a bound for client iğ‘–i:

The iğ‘–i-th constraint in (10b) is obtained by taking the expectation of the upper bounds in (6) and (15) when Pâˆ¼ğ’¬âˆ—similar-toğ‘ƒsuperscriptğ’¬P\sim\mathcal{Q}^{*} and Pâˆ¼ğ’«similar-toğ‘ƒğ’«P\sim\mathcal{P}, respectively, and enforcing that the former is smaller than the latter. âˆ

According to Corollary 8.0.1, participating in FL is beneficial for client iğ‘–i if the iğ‘–i-th constraint is satisfied. However, since we solved the constrained problem per (10a)-(10b) using the Lagrange method with a single multiplier, the constraints might be violated. The constraints are more likely to be satisfied when Ï„ğœ\tau is large, which can be achieved by having small nğ‘›n, n2subscriptğ‘›2n_{2}, and Î²ğ›½\beta, while simultaneously having a large value for Î»Esubscriptğœ†ğ¸\lambda_{E}. In other words, when there are fewer clients participating in FL, the hyper-posterior is more likely to provide improvements for those clients.

Remark.

In a similar manner, we can avoid any PAC arguments and use the principle of minimum cross entropy for calculating the posterior. With these two rules, the optimal posterior and hyper-posterior are the same as those obtained by minimizing client-level and server-level PAC bounds.

8.2 Proofs and derivations

We first mention without proof a powerful lemma, called the change of measure inequality, that is the basis of proving PAC bounds in most papers. The statement below is adapted from the Appendix of Pentina and Lampert [2014].

8.2.1 Proof of TheoremÂ 4.1

The proof of TheoremÂ 4.1 is carried out in three steps. The first two steps bound the true risk of clients with ğ’®~i=âˆ…subscript~ğ’®ğ‘–\tilde{\mathcal{S}}_{i}=\varnothing and clients with enlarged datasets, respectively. By merging these two, we will obtain a bound on the server-level true risk. In the last step, the closed-form formula of the optimal posterior is exploited to make some simplifications. The main assumptions are independence of clients (guaranteeing independence of Xksubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘˜X_{k} in Lemma 8.1), boundedness of the loss function (needed to apply CorollaryÂ 8.2.1), adoption of the optimal posterior (yielding the bound perÂ (6)), and existence of a finite Ïµâˆˆâ„+italic-Ïµsubscriptâ„\epsilon\in\mathbb{R}_{+} such that sampling Pğ‘ƒP from ğ’¬ğ’¬\mathcal{Q} preserves Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon-DP for all clients (required to use CorollaryÂ 3.1.1).

8.2.5 Looser upper bound for new clients

To compare the bound in Theorem 4.1 with Lemma 4.4, we can substitute the first two terms in Theorem 4.1 with (32). In order for the bound in Lemma 4.4 to be looser than this substituted bound, it is sufficient to show that âˆ‘i=1nÎ”i2â‰¤(bâˆ’a)2/nsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptÎ”ğ‘–2superscriptğ‘ğ‘2ğ‘›\sum_{i=1}^{n}\Delta_{i}^{2}\leq(b-a)^{2}/n, which is true based on the definition of Î”isubscriptÎ”ğ‘–\Delta_{i} in Theorem 4.1.

8.3 Details of the algorithm

8.3.1 Asymptotic behavior and non-vacuousness of bounds

We analyze the asymptotic behavior of the client-level and server-level bounds as the number of samples per client and the number of existing clients approach infinity, i.e., miâ†’âˆabsentâ†’subscriptğ‘šğ‘–m_{i}\xrightarrow{}{}\infty and nâ†’âˆabsentâ†’ğ‘›n\xrightarrow{}{}\infty. A PAC bound is considered consistent when the gap between the true and empirical risks goes to zero. The client-level and server-level bounds are consistent if and only if: a) Î²âˆˆÎ©â€‹(1)ğ›½Î©1\beta\in\Omega(1), b) Î²âˆˆoâ€‹(mi)ğ›½ğ‘œsubscriptğ‘šğ‘–\beta\in o(m_{i}), c) Î»âˆˆÎ©â€‹(n2)ğœ†Î©subscriptğ‘›2\lambda\in\Omega(n_{2}), d) Î»âˆˆoâ€‹(nâ€‹(n2+Ï…))ğœ†ğ‘œğ‘›subscriptğ‘›2ğœ\lambda\in o(n(n_{2}+\upsilon)). Here, oğ‘œo and Î©Î©\Omega represent the small-oh and big-omega notations for function growth rate [Cormen etÂ al., 2022].

Non-vacuous bounds are essential, ensuring that the terms independent of the posterior or the hyper-posterior are not excessively large such that the bound on the true loss holds regardless of the empirical loss. To achieve a non-vacuous bound, it is necessary (but not sufficient) that bâˆ’a<8ğ‘ğ‘8b-a<8 and that Ïµi<2â€‹(bâˆ’a)subscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘–2ğ‘ğ‘\epsilon_{i}<\sqrt{2(b-a)}. The latter condition can be converted into an upper bound on Î»ğœ†\lambda based on the results from Lemma 4.3.

In our experiments, we follow Rothfuss etÂ al. [2021] and set Î²=mi+m~iğ›½subscriptğ‘šğ‘–subscript~ğ‘šğ‘–\beta=m_{i}+\tilde{m}_{i}, leading to a non-vanishing gap between the true and empirical risks at the client and server levels. However, this choice simplifies the computations as discussed in Section 5. Moreover, this choice leads to faster decay of the KL term in both the client-level and server-level bounds, which can be advantageous when misubscriptğ‘šğ‘–m_{i} is small [Rothfuss etÂ al., 2021]. We tune Î»ğœ†\lambda, while respecting the non-vacuousness condition, to manipulate the regularization strength of the hyper-posterior towards the hyper-prior.

8.3.2 Background on GP

Below, we provide additional details regarding the GP models we use. For a more comprehensive overview on GPs, please refer to Rasmussen and Williams [2005]. In the rest of this section, we express the dataset of client iğ‘–i as ğ’®i=(ğ—i,ğ²i)subscriptğ’®ğ‘–subscriptğ—ğ‘–subscriptğ²ğ‘–\mathcal{S}_{i}=(\mathbf{X}_{i},\mathbf{y}_{i}), where ğ—iâˆˆRğ±miâŠ‚â„miÃ—dsubscriptğ—ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘…ğ±subscriptğ‘šğ‘–superscriptâ„subscriptğ‘šğ‘–ğ‘‘\mathbf{X}_{i}\in R_{\mathbf{x}}^{m_{i}}\subset\mathbb{R}^{m_{i}\times d} is a matrix with row jğ‘—j representing the features of the jğ‘—j-th sample in ğ’®isubscriptğ’®ğ‘–\mathcal{S}_{i} denoted as ğ±iâ€‹jâˆˆRğ±subscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ‘…ğ±\mathbf{x}_{ij}\in R_{\mathbf{x}}. The corresponding target values are stored in the vector ğ²iâˆˆRymiâŠ‚â„misubscriptğ²ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘…ğ‘¦subscriptğ‘šğ‘–superscriptâ„subscriptğ‘šğ‘–\mathbf{y}_{i}\in R_{y}^{m_{i}}\subset\mathbb{R}^{m_{i}}, with row jğ‘—j representing the target value yiâ€‹jâˆˆRysubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ‘…ğ‘¦y_{ij}\in R_{y}.

GP with a deep mean and a deep kernel [Wilson etÂ al., 2016].

Let PÏ•â€‹(h)=ğ’¢â€‹ğ’«â€‹(h|mÏ•â€‹(ğ±),kÏ•â€‹(ğ±,ğ±â€²))subscriptğ‘ƒbold-italic-Ï•â„ğ’¢ğ’«conditionalâ„subscriptğ‘šbold-italic-Ï•ğ±subscriptğ‘˜bold-italic-Ï•ğ±superscriptğ±â€²P_{\bm{\phi}}(h)=\mathcal{GP}(h|m_{\bm{\phi}}(\mathbf{x}),k_{\bm{\phi}}(\mathbf{x},\mathbf{x^{\prime}})) denote a GP prior specified by a deep mean function, mÏ•subscriptğ‘šbold-italic-Ï•m_{\bm{\phi}}, a deep kernel function, kÏ•subscriptğ‘˜bold-italic-Ï•k_{\bm{\phi}}, and a Gaussian likelihood with noise standard deviation, ÏƒÏ•âˆˆâ„+subscriptğœbold-italic-Ï•subscriptâ„\sigma_{\bm{\phi}}\in\mathbb{R}_{+}. The vector Ï•âˆˆâ„dÏ•bold-italic-Ï•superscriptâ„subscriptğ‘‘italic-Ï•\bm{\phi}\in\mathbb{R}^{d_{\phi}} concatenates all learnable hyper-parameters of the GP prior, including the mean parameters, kernel parameters, and the likelihood noise. The mean function, mÏ•:Rğ±â†’â„:subscriptğ‘šbold-italic-Ï•absentâ†’subscriptğ‘…ğ±â„m_{\bm{\phi}}:R_{\mathbf{x}}\xrightarrow[]{}\mathbb{R}, is implemented as a multi-layer NN with weights given by Ï•bold-italic-Ï•{\bm{\phi}}, hyperbolic tangent activation functions in the hidden layers, and linear output functions in the output layer. The kernel function is a squared-exponential (SE) kernel applied on top of an NN, defined as:

kÏ•â€‹(ğ±,ğ±â€²)â‰”eâ€‹xâ€‹pâ€‹(âˆ’12â€‹â€–fÏ•â€‹(ğ±)âˆ’fÏ•â€‹(ğ±â€²)â€–22)âˆˆ[0,1].â‰”subscriptğ‘˜bold-italic-Ï•ğ±superscriptğ±â€²ğ‘’ğ‘¥ğ‘12superscriptsubscriptnormsubscriptğ‘“bold-italic-Ï•ğ±subscriptğ‘“bold-italic-Ï•superscriptğ±â€²2201\displaystyle k_{\bm{\phi}}(\mathbf{x},\mathbf{x^{\prime}})\coloneqq exp(\frac{-1}{2}\|f_{\bm{\phi}}(\mathbf{x})-f_{\bm{\phi}}(\mathbf{x^{\prime}})\|_{2}^{2})\in[0,1].

The function fÏ•:Rğ±â†’â„df:subscriptğ‘“bold-italic-Ï•absentâ†’subscriptğ‘…ğ±superscriptâ„subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘“f_{\bm{\phi}}:R_{\mathbf{x}}\xrightarrow[]{}\mathbb{R}^{d_{f}} represents an NN with weights given by Ï•bold-italic-Ï•{\bm{\phi}} that maps the typically high-dimensional feature vector, ğ±âˆˆRğ±âŠ‚â„dğ±subscriptğ‘…ğ±superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathbf{x}\in R_{\mathbf{x}}\subset\mathbb{R}^{d}, to a lower-dimensional output vector in â„dfsuperscriptâ„subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘“\mathbb{R}^{d_{f}}, where in our specific case, dfsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘“d_{f} is two. Deep kernels serve as feature extractors and allow for learning more sophisticated representations from the data [Ober etÂ al., 2021]. The length scale of the SE kernel is set to 111 because the weights of the output layer of fÏ•subscriptğ‘“bold-italic-Ï•f_{\bm{\phi}} can be freely chosen to compensate for it.

Computing the LML.

As mentioned in Section 5, when employing a GP prior, negative log likelihood loss, and setting Î²=miğ›½subscriptğ‘šğ‘–\beta=m_{i}, the quantity lnâ¡ZmiCâ€‹(P,ğ’®i)superscriptsubscriptğ‘subscriptğ‘šğ‘–ğ¶ğ‘ƒsubscriptğ’®ğ‘–\ln Z_{m_{i}}^{C}(P,\mathcal{S}_{i}) defined in CorollaryÂ 3.1.1 corresponds to the LML of the GP. For client iğ‘–i using the prior PÏ•Îºsubscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptbold-italic-Ï•ğœ…P_{\bm{\phi}_{\kappa}}, the closed-form formula for the LML is as follows:

where ğ¦Îº,iâˆˆâ„misubscriptğ¦ğœ…ğ‘–superscriptâ„subscriptğ‘šğ‘–\mathbf{m}_{\kappa,i}\in\mathbb{R}^{m_{i}} is given by [mÏ•Îºâ€‹(ğ±iâ€‹1),â‹¯,mÏ•Îºâ€‹(ğ±iâ€‹mi)]Tsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘šsubscriptbold-italic-Ï•ğœ…subscriptğ±ğ‘–1â‹¯subscriptğ‘šsubscriptbold-italic-Ï•ğœ…subscriptğ±ğ‘–subscriptğ‘šğ‘–ğ‘‡[m_{\bm{\phi}_{\kappa}}(\mathbf{x}_{i1}),\cdots,m_{\bm{\phi}_{\kappa}}(\mathbf{x}_{im_{i}})]^{T} and |ğ€|ğ€|\mathbf{A}| denotes the determinant of the matrix ğ€ğ€\mathbf{A}. The matrix ğŠÎº,iâˆˆâ„miÃ—misubscriptğŠğœ…ğ‘–superscriptâ„subscriptğ‘šğ‘–subscriptğ‘šğ‘–\mathbf{K}_{\kappa,i}\in\mathbb{R}^{m_{i}\times m_{i}} is the kernel matrix associated with the kernel function kÏ•Îºsubscriptğ‘˜subscriptbold-italic-Ï•ğœ…k_{\bm{\phi}_{\kappa}} applied to the feature matrix ğ—isubscriptğ—ğ‘–\mathbf{X}_{i}. Furthermore, ğŠÎº,i,âˆ—âˆˆâ„misubscriptğŠğœ…ğ‘–superscriptâ„subscriptğ‘šğ‘–\mathbf{K}_{\kappa,i,*}\in\mathbb{R}^{m_{i}} is computed using the kernel function kÏ•Îºsubscriptğ‘˜subscriptbold-italic-Ï•ğœ…k_{\bm{\phi}_{\kappa}} between the feature matrix ğ—isubscriptğ—ğ‘–\mathbf{X}_{i} and the test features ğ±âˆ—subscriptğ±\mathbf{x}_{*}.

The determinant term is commonly viewed as a complexity penalty for the kernel [Rasmussen and Williams, 2005]. However, recent findings in Rothfuss etÂ al. [2021] suggest that this form of complexity regularization may be inadequate when dealing with expressive kernels that possess numerous hyperparameters, such as deep kernels. Furthermore, there is no complexity penalty imposed on the prior mean, which can lead to a higher risk of overfitting. In PAC-PFL, we address these limitations by using (9) as the loss function, which includes a KL divergence term between the hyper-posterior and the hyper-prior. The KL term penalizes hyper-posteriors that deviate significantly from the hyper-prior, thereby effectively regularizing both the mean and the kernel of the GP prior.

By merging (34)-(36), one obtains

8.3.4 Background on SVGD

SVGD approximates a target probability distribution using a discrete uniform distribution over a set of designated samples called particles [Liu and Wang, 2016]. Through an iterative process, the particles are updated by minimizing the KL divergence between the estimated and the target distributions in the reproducing kernel Hilbert space corresponding to a kernel function, kSâ€‹Vâ€‹Gâ€‹Dsubscriptğ‘˜ğ‘†ğ‘‰ğºğ·k_{SVGD}. We utilize an RBF (Radial Basis Function) kernel with a heuristically chosen length scale, as described in Liu and Wang [2016]. In our framework, we aim to obtain samples PÏ•1,â‹¯,PÏ•ksubscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptbold-italic-Ï•1â‹¯subscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptbold-italic-Ï•ğ‘˜P_{\bm{\phi}_{1}},\cdots,P_{\bm{\phi}_{k}} from the target distribution ğ’¬âˆ—superscriptğ’¬\mathcal{Q}^{*}. To simplify the notation, we represent the particles as Ï•1,â‹¯,Ï•ksubscriptbold-italic-Ï•1â‹¯subscriptbold-italic-Ï•ğ‘˜\bm{\phi}_{1},\cdots,\bm{\phi}_{k}, where each particle Ï•Îºsubscriptbold-italic-Ï•ğœ…\bm{\phi}_{\kappa} fully characterizes the corresponding prior, PÏ•Îºsubscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptbold-italic-Ï•ğœ…P_{\bm{\phi}_{\kappa}}. Accordingly, we write ğ’«â€‹(Ï•Îº)ğ’«subscriptbold-italic-Ï•ğœ…\mathcal{P}(\bm{\phi}_{\kappa}) and ğ’¬âˆ—â€‹(Ï•Îº)superscriptğ’¬subscriptbold-italic-Ï•ğœ…\mathcal{Q}^{*}(\bm{\phi}_{\kappa}) instead of ğ’«â€‹(PÏ•Îº)ğ’«subscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptbold-italic-Ï•ğœ…\mathcal{P}(P_{\bm{\phi}_{\kappa}}) and ğ’¬âˆ—â€‹(PÏ•Îº)superscriptğ’¬subscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptbold-italic-Ï•ğœ…\mathcal{Q}^{*}(P_{\bm{\phi}_{\kappa}}).

Initially, the particles are sampled independently from the hyper-prior. Then, at each iteration, each particle Ï•Îºsubscriptbold-italic-Ï•ğœ…\bm{\phi}_{\kappa} for Îºâˆˆ{1,â‹¯,k}ğœ…1â‹¯ğ‘˜\kappa\in\{1,\cdots,k\} is updated according to the following rule:

8.3.7 Computational complexity

In this section, we discuss the computational complexity of a single iteration in training PAC-PFL, specifically when employing the log-likelihood loss and Î²=miğ›½subscriptğ‘šğ‘–\beta=m_{i}, as outlined in the paper. At the client level, the computational complexity hinges on the calculation of the LML. For GPs, this complexity is ğ’ªâ€‹(kâ€‹mi3)ğ’ªğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘šğ‘–3\mathcal{O}(km_{i}^{3}), where kğ‘˜k is the number of SVGD particles, and misubscriptğ‘šğ‘–m_{i} denotes the size of the training dataset for the specific client iğ‘–i. For BNNs, the complexity is ğ’ªâ€‹(kâ€‹Lâ€‹mi)ğ’ªğ‘˜ğ¿subscriptğ‘šğ‘–\mathcal{O}(kLm_{i}), where Lğ¿L corresponds to the number of samples used to approximate the LML, as explained in Appendix 8.3.3.

At the server level, the computational complexity varies based on the type of hyper-prior used. When utilizing a hyper-prior with a diagonal covariance matrix, the complexity is ğ’ªâ€‹(câ€‹k+k2)ğ’ªğ‘ğ‘˜superscriptğ‘˜2\mathcal{O}(ck+k^{2}), where cğ‘c represents the number of clients selected per iteration. If a hyper-prior with a full covariance matrix is used, the complexity increases to ğ’ªâ€‹(câ€‹k+k3)ğ’ªğ‘ğ‘˜superscriptğ‘˜3\mathcal{O}(ck+k^{3}).

8.4 Role of DP

We adopt DP in two key ways. Firstly, we utilize DP to ensure that when the server samples a prior distribution from the hyper-posterior and releases it, this published prior distribution does not raise privacy concerns for the existing clients. This application is akin to typical scenarios in FL research where DP is used to protect the model shared by the server from revealing information about clientsâ€™ data. Besides addressing privacy concerns, we use DP to establish a PAC bound at the client level. As illustrated in Fig. 1, our setup involves prior distributions that depend on the data of existing clients. While most PAC bounds assume the prior distribution was selected before observing any data, we leverage results from Dziugaite and Roy [2018] to derive a PAC bound that holds when a data-dependent prior is obtained through a differentially private algorithm. To the best of our knowledge, DP has not been employed for this purpose in previous FL methods. Below, we discuss the role of DP in our ideal setup (Section 4) and our practical algorithm (Section 5).

Inherent privacy of the optimal hyper-posterior

In Section 4, we considered a specific family of hyper-posteriors, where sampling a prior from the hyper-posterior satisfies Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon-DP for a finite Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon. This assumption simplifies computations and enables us to use the closed-form posterior provided in Corollary 3.1.1. We then established the server-level upper bound in Theorem 4.1 for hyper-posteriors meeting the privacy criterion. Interestingly, the resulting upper bound does not contain the parameter Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon. This can be intuitively explained by the fact that the hyper-prior is chosen independently of the data, making the server-level scheme akin to typical PAC-Bayesian bounds that employ data-independent priors. Additional details can be found in the proof presented in Appendix 8.2. In summary, the Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon-DP assumption facilitates the computations by allowing us to use the optimal posterior formula without directly impacting the server-level bound.

By minimizing the server-level upper bound, we derived the closed-form formula for the optimal hyper-posterior in Corollary 4.2.1. Subsequently, we ensured that the optimal hyper-posterior satisfies the privacy assumption we started with. To achieve this, Lemma 4.3 determined the value of Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon for which sampling the prior from the optimal hyper-posterior meets Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon-DP. As this Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon is finite, it confirms that our optimal hyper-posterior belongs to the family of hyper-posteriors we initially considered, thus completing the derivations. While assuming a finite Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon is sufficient for deriving the intended results, it is worth noting that the client-level bound becomes looser for larger values of Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon. Further discussion on providing non-vacuous bounds can be found in Appendix 8.3.1.

In the ideal setup, DP arises from the inherent randomness in sampling from the optimal hyper-posterior. As a result, DP is achieved without the need for externally injecting noise, which is a common practice in typical DP mechanisms. We refer to this property as the inherent DP of the optimal hyper-posterior.

Loss of inherent DP due to SVGD

As discussed in Section 5, since SVGD is a deterministic sampling algorithm, we forfeit the inherent privacy of ğ’¬âˆ—superscriptğ’¬\mathcal{Q}^{*}. Consequently, the client-level and server-level bounds no longer hold for the approximate hyper-posterior. Instead, we rely on the premise that if SVGD effectively approximates the optimal hyper-posterior, the empirical and true risks of the approximated and optimal hyper-posteriors should be closely aligned, suggesting the boundâ€™s validity.

Differentially private PAC-PFL

To reintroduce Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon-DP after SVGD approximation, Algorithm 1 can be modified, drawing inspiration from differentially private FedAvg [Geyer etÂ al., 2017]. In this modified version, the server clips the norm of the gradient sent by each client and introduces noise to the aggregated gradient. For simplicity, we will illustrate the algorithm using only one SVGD particle. A pseudo-code for this private version of PAC-PFL is provided in Algorithm 4.

As we are considering a single particle in Algorithm 4, the Client_Update function returns a vector ğ’ˆisubscriptğ’ˆğ‘–\bm{g}_{i} instead of a matrix ğ‘®isubscriptğ‘®ğ‘–\bm{G}_{i}, as is the case when using multiple SVGD particles. In Algorithm 4, the notation Lâ€‹aâ€‹pâ€‹(ğŸ,Tâ€‹Î³Ïµâ€‹câ€‹ğ‘°â€‹dâ€‹Ï•)ğ¿ğ‘ğ‘0ğ‘‡ğ›¾italic-Ïµğ‘ğ‘°ğ‘‘bold-italic-Ï•Lap(\bm{0},\frac{T\gamma}{\epsilon c}\bm{I}{d{\bm{\phi}}}) represents a multivariate Laplace probability distribution. In this context, ğŸ0\bm{0} denotes a zero mean vector, and Tâ€‹Î³Ïµâ€‹câ€‹ğ‘°â€‹dâ€‹Ï•ğ‘‡ğ›¾italic-Ïµğ‘ğ‘°ğ‘‘bold-italic-Ï•\frac{T\gamma}{\epsilon c}\bm{I}{d{\bm{\phi}}} specifies the scale parameter applied across all dimensions. Both the particle, Ï•bold-italic-Ï•\bm{\phi}, and the noise vector, Î½ğœˆ\nu, have dimension dÏ•subscriptğ‘‘bold-italic-Ï•d_{\bm{\phi}}.

The noise scale in Algorithm 4 grows linearly with the number of iterations, Tğ‘‡T. This can introduce significant noise into the gradients, potentially impairing both convergence and the overall accuracy of the algorithm. This challenge is intrinsic to differentially private gradient descent and is not unique to our model or FL in general [Bagdasaryan etÂ al., 2019]. Investigating alternative strategies to achieve Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon-DP remains a promising avenue for future research.

We assess the performance of Algorithm 4 using the Polynomial dataset, introduced in Appendix 8.5. Specifically, we use 120120120 existing clients, each with 101010 samples. We vary the privacy parameter Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon and examine its impact on the algorithmâ€™s performance, measured by the average RSMSE metric. Fig.Â 3 illustrates the RSMSE across different values of Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon. Additionally, we plot the RSMSE of the non-private algorithm, Algorithm 1, in red for reference. As anticipated, the modelâ€™s performance improves as Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon increases, signifying a lower level of privacy and consequently reduced noise requirements.

8.5 Datasets

8.5.1 PV dataset

The transition to renewable energy sources, such as roof-top photovoltaic (PV) panels, is crucial to address energy challenges; however, the intermittency of solar energy remains a challenge that requires accurate prediction of solar panel power output. Predicting the time series of PV panel power outputs requires either specific measurements or large amounts of data. A potential solution is to design a collaborative methodology among multiple PV datasets collected at nearby locations for predictive modeling.

We work with an hourly simulated dataset of PV generation time series from rooftop panels in Lausanne, Switzerland. Our objective is to predict the next-hour PV generation, utilizing 151515 features encompassing auto-regressors and weather data. We investigate four scenarios: PV-S (150), PV-S (610), PV-EW (150), and PV-EW (610). In the PV-S variants, all houses face south, while the PV-EW variants involve houses oriented either east or west. The PV-EW scenarios, being bimodal and highly heterogeneous, present greater modeling challenges. To assess the impact of dataset sizes (denoted as ğ¦ğ¦\mathbf{m}), we consider two settings: clients with either 150150150 or 610610610 training samples, corresponding to two-week and two-month data windows, respectively. The number in each datasetâ€™s name indicates the training sample size.

Data generation.

To generate simulated datasets for the PV-S and PV-EW experiments, we first obtained a real dataset of hourly solar radiation and meteorological measurements in Lausanne from the Photovoltaic Geographical Information System (PVGIS) online tool [PVG, ]. We then used the pvlib Python library [Holmgren etÂ al., 2022] to simulate the PV power output based on these measurements. To simulate the PV panels in different houses, we sampled meteorological data and installation specifications from normal distributions with specified means and standard deviations. For example, in the PV-EW experiment, the azimuths of the PV panels were sampled from a bimodal normal distribution of 0.5â€‹(ğ’©â€‹(90âˆ˜,15âˆ˜)+ğ’©â€‹(270âˆ˜,15âˆ˜))0.5ğ’©superscript90superscript15ğ’©superscript270superscript150.5\big{(}\mathcal{N}(90^{\circ},15^{\circ})+\mathcal{N}(270^{\circ},15^{\circ})\big{)}, where ğ’©ğ’©\mathcal{N} denotes the normal distribution. Fig.Â 4 illustrates the power output profiles of 24 houses in the PV-EW experiment over five days. This figure demonstrates that the curves have noticeable differences; however, they show similar trends. As expected, the houses facing east or west are more similar to one another, while the differences among different sub-populations are higher. For instance, the peak production of the houses facing the east occurs in the morning, whereas the peak for those facing the west occurs in the afternoon.

To ensure that each clientâ€™s dataset is identically distributed, despite the variations in meteorological patterns throughout the year, we filter the dataset down to the months of June and July. We employ two distinct training datasets for our analysis. The first dataset comprises the initial two weeks of June 201820182018, which provides a total of 150150150 samples for each client. The second dataset encompasses the data from both June and July 201820182018, resulting in 610610610 training samples per client. For all experiments, the test dataset consists of the data from June and July 201920192019. Furthermore, we exclude nighttime data points when the PV generation is zero. To normalize the data, we standardize each houseâ€™s features and output, setting the mean to zero and the standard deviation to one.

Features.

The dataset contains various meteorological features, including solar beam and diffuse irradiances, temperature, wind speed, solar altitude, time, and date. Solar beam and diffuse irradiances are particularly valuable in predicting PV generation, but their measurement can be costly. To reflect a realistic scenario, we assume that all households have access to the irradiance data recorded at a specific location in the city, such as a weather station. However, they are unaware of the specific irradiance values at their own houses, which may differ from the weather station. The temperature and wind speed may vary slightly among different houses in the dataset. Additionally, some houses may experience intermittent shadows caused by nearby trees or buildings, which can appear and disappear at certain times of the day. These shadows are considered as noise, and no recorded feature in the dataset provides explicit information about their occurrence or characteristics.

In addition to the meteorological features, we also incorporate autoregressors in our analysis. Autoregressors are advantageous in time-series prediction tasks and aim to capture the temporal dependencies in the data. To determine the autoregressors to include in our analysis, we utilize the partial autocorrelation function (PACF). The PACF measures the correlation between a time series and its lagged values while controlling for the correlations with all shorter lags. We select autoregressors with the highest values of the PACF among the lagged values up to two weeks ago. By focusing on these highly correlated autoregressors, we aim to capture the most relevant information from the past time steps.

8.5.2 Polynomial dataset

We examine a bimodal dataset where the data for each client is generated by sampling a function from one of two GP priors. Each GP prior is characterized by a polynomial mean function of order 777 and an SE kernel function. The two modes have distinct polynomial means and length scales associated with the SE kernel. Additionally, Gaussian noise is introduced into the generated data to account for measurement errors and other sources of variability. Fig.Â 5 illustrates the dataset for a total of 242424 clients, with 121212 clients belonging to the first mode and another 121212 clients belonging to the second mode, where each client has 101010 training samples.

8.5.3 FEMNIST and EMNIST Datasets

The FEMNIST (Federated Extended MNIST)Â [Caldas etÂ al., 2019] and EMNIST (Extended MNIST)Â [Cohen etÂ al., 2017] datasets consist of 28Ã—28282828\times 28 images of hand-written English characters. Both datasets are used for handwritten character recognition. Specifically, the FEMNIST dataset is employed in a 101010-way classification task, focusing on the classification of digits. Meanwhile, the EMNIST dataset is utilized for a more comprehensive 626262-way classification task. This broader task encompasses the recognition of both lower case and upper case English alphabet letters, in addition to digits.

FEMNIST identifies the writer for each character, allowing a natural partitioning strategy by assigning all images from the same writer to a single clientÂ [Caldas etÂ al., 2019]. This dataset is heterogeneous due to the inherent diversity in handwriting styles, resulting in skewness within the feature distributionÂ [Tan etÂ al., 2021]. For our analysis, we subsample 404040 clients and explore two scenarios: FEMNIST (202020), where each client is allocated 202020 samples and FEMNIST (500500500), where each client utilizes all available samples, approximately 500500500 per client.

Following Â [Wang etÂ al., 2020, Marfoq etÂ al., 2021], we subsample 10%percent1010\% of the EMNIST dataset that amounts to 814258142581425 total samples. We distribute samples with the same label across 808080 clients according to a symmetric Dirichlet distribution with parameter Î±=0.4ğ›¼0.4\alpha=0.4. This approach introduces a skew in the label distributionÂ [Tan etÂ al., 2021], thereby synthesizing heterogeneity in the dataset.

8.6 Experiments details

8.6.1 Calibration error

Calibration error (CE) is an evaluation metric relevant to probabilistic models. It is based on the premise that when provided with a test input ğ±jsubscriptğ±ğ‘—\mathbf{x}_{j}, the model produces a probability distribution p^â€‹(yj|ğ±j)^ğ‘conditionalsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘—subscriptğ±ğ‘—\hat{p}(y_{j}|\mathbf{x}_{j}) over the predicted target yjsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘—y_{j}. CE measures the disparity between the predicted confidence intervals and the actual proportions of test data falling within those intervalsÂ [Kuleshov etÂ al., 2018]. CE is a nonnegative measure and a smaller CE value is more desirable.

Calibration error for regression.

In defining CE for regression, we follow the formula proposed byÂ [Rothfuss etÂ al., 2021]. For a well-calibrated classifier, the confidence is expected to align with the probability of correct classification. For example, with 100100100 predictions, each having a confidence of 0.80.80.8, one would anticipate approximately 808080 correct classifications [Guo etÂ al., 2017]. In an empirical comparison of calibration and accuracy on a dataset ğ’®={(ğ±j,yj)}j=1mğ’®superscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ±ğ‘—subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘—ğ‘—1ğ‘š\mathcal{S}=\bigl{\{}(\mathbf{x}_{j},y_{j})\bigr{\}}_{j=1}^{m}, following the methodology of Guo etÂ al.
